response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second and fifth circuits. [CHUNK_6] This measure was amended to delete language that would have established a program in the Third Circuit, instead requiring the Third Circuit and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study for a future program. [CHUNK_34] The judiciary is required to submit annual reports on the pilot program, which is scheduled to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_11]",
  "appropriations": "The bill appropriates unspecified sums from the general revenues for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [CHUNK_15] A committee report requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [CHUNK_37] This request includes $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a clinical psychologist, $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a social worker, and $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a social services assistant. [CHUNK_38]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The bill does not specify the methodology for its blank appropriation amounts. [CHUNK_15] The committee report provides a cost breakdown for the Department of Health positions, suggesting the appropriation request is based on salary and benefit calculations for specific roles. [CHUNK_38] The request details funding for one full-time equivalent for a temporary clinical psychologist position, a temporary social worker/human services professional IV position, and a temporary social services assistant V position. [CHUNK_38]",
  "agency_impact": "This measure was amended to include appropriations for both the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [CHUNK_35] The women's court pilot program shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary. [CHUNK_8] The sums appropriated for specific clinical and social work positions shall be expended by the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_21]",
  "economic_impact": "The pilot program's goal is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [CHUNK_9] The measure seeks to address barriers such as lack of stable work history and economic marginalization to improve outcomes for women offenders. [CHUNK_33] This is based on research showing that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. [CHUNK_32]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure was amended by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [CHUNK_34] It instead requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. [CHUNK_21] The bill still requires the Judiciary to submit recommendations as to whether the pilot program should continue as a pilot program, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_14]",
  "revenue_sources": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for the Judiciary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_15] A separate appropriation is made from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for the Department of Health for the same fiscal years. [CHUNK_18] No other revenue sources are mentioned in the provided documents. [CHUNK_18]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill appropriates an unspecified sum from general revenues to the Judiciary for FY 2025-2026 and FY 2026-2027. [CHUNK_15] It also appropriates an unspecified sum from general revenues to the Department of Health for the same two fiscal years. [CHUNK_19] The committee report requests that the Finance Committee consider an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [CHUNK_37] This amount is intended to fund a 1.0 FTE temporary clinical psychologist position at $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), a 1.0 FTE temporary social worker at $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), and a 1.0 FTE temporary social services assistant at $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt). [CHUNK_38] The bill was amended to change the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount. [CHUNK_35] The committee report also requests consideration for establishing seven temporary positions in the Judiciary. [CHUNK_37] The pilot program is established for three years and is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_23] The third circuit of the judiciary is required to submit a report on resource requirements for a future program. [CHUNK_22] Any fiscal implications beyond the pilot period are contingent on future legislative action. [CHUNK_14]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not indicate any anticipated impact on operating revenues. [CHUNK_15] The bill is funded through appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_18] No fees, fines, or other revenue-generating mechanisms are mentioned. [CHUNK_18]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_16] The appropriation for the Judiciary is for equipment, mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, and the establishment of temporary positions. [CHUNK_16] No investments in facilities or major infrastructure are mentioned. [CHUNK_16]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The women's court pilot program is a temporary, three-year program that shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_23] The judiciary is required to submit a report with recommendations as to whether the program should be continued, expanded, or discontinued. [CHUNK_14] Any fiscal obligations after the repeal date will depend on future legislation based on the program's outcomes and the judiciary's recommendations. [CHUNK_14]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The bill has been significantly amended since the previous version. [CHUNK_34] The pilot program's scope was reduced from the second, third, and fifth circuits to only the second and fifth circuits, with the third circuit now tasked with conducting a study. [CHUNK_34] A new appropriation for the Department of Health was inserted, and a committee report suggests an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to fund three positions. [CHUNK_37] The bill's effective date was changed from a fixed date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_36]",
  "fte_positions": "The bill was amended by changing the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount. [CHUNK_35] It newly provides for the establishment of temporary positions within the Department of Health. [CHUNK_19] A committee report requests funding for three specific temporary positions in the Department of Health: one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) clinical psychologist, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) social worker/human services professional IV, and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) social services assistant V. [CHUNK_38]",
  "appropriations_changes": "The bill was amended by inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_36] This is in addition to the existing unspecified appropriation for the Judiciary. [CHUNK_15] A committee report requests that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [CHUNK_37]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The method of funding has not changed. [CHUNK_15] Appropriations for both the Judiciary and the Department of Health are appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_18] There have been no changes to the funding source between versions of the bill. [CHUNK_18]",
  "department_impact": "Departmental responsibility for expending appropriations has been changed. [CHUNK_36] The bill was amended by inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_36] The sums appropriated shall now be expended by both the judiciary and the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_21]",
  "reports_required": "A new reporting requirement has been added to the measure. [CHUNK_34] The third circuit of the judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations for establishing a pilot program to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026. [CHUNK_22] This is in addition to the annual reports from the judiciary on the status of the pilot program in the second and fifth circuits, which are due prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [CHUNK_12]",
  "pilot_program": "The scope of the pilot program was amended. [CHUNK_34] The bill was changed by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [CHUNK_34] The pilot program is now established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary. [CHUNK_8]",
  "sunset_date": "The sunset date for the bill has not changed. [CHUNK_23] The Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_23]",
  "effective_date": "The bill was amended by changing the effective date to July 1, 3000. [CHUNK_36] This change was made to encourage further discussion on the measure. [CHUNK_36]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB727 HD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 727 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a

SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawaii jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance

for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work

for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the

women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January

therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August, 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The

treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second and fifth circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system

distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (2) Require the third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. PART II

women's court pilot program in the third circuit. PART II SECTION 2. (a) There shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to

employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health

shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing

abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. SECTION 3. The judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, to the governor and legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and

the convening of the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028 , regarding: (1) The status of the women's court pilot program; (2) The number of women accepted into the women's court pilot program; (3) The number of women who were eligible to participate in the women's court pilot program

were eligible to participate in the women's court pilot program but who could not be accepted into the pilot program because of pilot program limitations; (4) The number of women completing the women's court pilot program; (5) The number of women who were removed from the women's court pilot program;

women who were removed from the women's court pilot program; and (6) Recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should: (A) Continue as a pilot program; (B) Expand to include additional participants; (C) Provide additional services; or (D) Be discontinued. thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of temporary positions as follows: (1) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker V positions; (2) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker IV positions; (3) full-time equivalent ( FTE)

FTE) social worker IV positions; (3) full-time equivalent ( FTE) circuit court clerk II positions; and (4) full-time equivalent ( FTE) judicial clerk positions; for the women's court pilot program established pursuant to section 2 of this Act. as follows: (1) $ for full-time equivalent ( FTE) clinical psychologist position; (2) $ for full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker/human services professional IV position; and (3) $ for full-time equivalent ( FTE) social services assistant V position. HSCR624 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 624 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled:

Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary

in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. Specifically, this measure: (1) Requires the pilot program to implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism; (2) Appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services;

for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions for the pilot program; and (3) Requires the Judiciary to submit annual reports on the pilot program throughout its duration. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of

testimony in support of this measure from the Department of Health; Judiciary; Office of the Public Defender; Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Kaua ʻ i; Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui; Community Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women

Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women Voters of Hawaii; American Civil Liberties Union of Hawai ʻ i; and two individuals. Your Committee finds that research has shown that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women

women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women offenders are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization. This measure seeks to address these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. Your Committee

these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. unspecified amount; (3) Inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions; (4) Changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion; and (5) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a

SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawaii jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance

for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work

for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the

women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January

therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August, 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The

treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (2) Require the third circuit of the judiciary and big island drug court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. women's court pilot program in the third circuit. PART II SECTION 2. (a) There shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary

in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. Specifically, this measure: (1) Requires the pilot program to implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism; (2) Appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services;

for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions for the pilot program; and (3) Requires the Judiciary to submit annual reports on the pilot program throughout its duration. Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women Voters of Hawaii; American Civil Liberties Union of Hawai ʻ i; and two individuals. Your Committee finds that research has shown that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women

women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders.
